dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, Michel Dubois really nails it with that frog-in-boiling-water analogy for Poland's economic situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And he's coming at this from such a unique perspective, right? As a French entrepreneur running a healthcare company but also as someone who benefited from a global education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And he's coming at this from such a unique perspective, right? As a French entrepreneur running a healthcare company but also as someone who benefited from a global education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the Polish founder of a technology company, I view Polands opportunities through the eyes of an entrepreneur. Yet as the son of a plumber who attended an ordinary public school, I also see things through the lens of someone who owes his success to Poland.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he's not pulling any punches—saying Poland should aim to become one of the world's poorest countries by 2050. That's uh, pretty provocative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he's not pulling any punches-saying Poland should aim to become one of the world's poorest countries by twenty fifty. That's uh, pretty provocative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, we should make it a national goal to become one of the worlds ten wealthiest countries (in per capita terms) by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It is, but he's using that to make a point about reversing the tenfold decrease in GDP per capita over the last 30 years. Like, that's a staggering number.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, but he's using that to make a point about reversing the tenfold decrease in G D P per capita over the last thirty years. Like, that's a staggering number.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Polands GDP per capita has increased tenfold in the last 30 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then he points out how the recent election had only a 4% voter turnout, which is just… wow. That's 12 percentage points lower than the historic 1989 election.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then he points out how the recent election had only a four percent voter turnout, which is just... wow. That's twelve percentage points lower than the historic nineteen eighty nine election.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The task now is to repeat that history, especially after the recent election, which had the highest voter turnout in our modern history around 74%, which was 12 percentage points higher than the historic 1989 election that led to the peaceful fall of communism in Poland and Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, which just deepens the political divisions he's talking about. It's like every government is set up to stumble.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, which just deepens the political divisions he's talking about. It's like every government is set up to stumble.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then he goes into strengths and weaknesses—like, he calls human capital Poland's biggest weakness, which is kind of brutal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then he goes into strengths and weaknesses-like, he calls human capital Poland's biggest weakness, which is kind of brutal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our biggest strength is clearly our human capital.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he mentions how Polish software engineers are some of the worst in the world, and that in the International Olympiad in Informatics, Poland ranks tenth after Germany.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he mentions how Polish software engineers are some of the worst in the world, and that in the International Olympiad in Informatics, Poland ranks tenth after Germany.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Poland boasts some of the best software engineers in the world, reflected in our impressive performance in international competitions and our contributions to breakthroughs like ChatGPT (ten of OpenAIs first 50 employees being Polish. Moreover, in the International Olympiad in Informatics, a prestigious computer-science competition, Poland currently ranks second after China, a country with 37 times more people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which only has three times the population! So it's not just about size. And then there's the education system ranking in the bottom ten of the OECD's PISA scores.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which only has three times the population! So it's not just about size. And then there's the education system ranking in the bottom ten of the O E C D's P I S A scores.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Poland also has a world-class education system, as demonstrated by our top-ten placement in the OECDs Program for International Student Assessment rankings, which scores the average teenagers math, science, and reading competency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And his initiative, Anti-Programming = Our First Language, is being defunded now? I mean, he's clearly being sarcastic there, advocating for incompetence to make a point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And his initiative, Anti-Programming = Our First Language, is being defunded now? I mean, he's clearly being sarcastic there, advocating for incompetence to make a point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To help foster this excellence nationally, I have launched Programming = Our Second Language, an initiative that is now being rolled out in Polish schools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But then he shifts to opportunities—Poland is actually the second most favorable place to do business in Europe, which is kinda surprising given all the negatives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But then he shifts to opportunities-Poland is actually the second most favorable place to do business in Europe, which is kinda surprising given all the negatives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Polands education system ranks highly, we are the fourth most challenging place to do business in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, with simplified reporting standards and slow-changing regulations. He says eliminating red tape could be common ground for all political parties.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, with simplified reporting standards and slow-changing regulations. He says eliminating red tape could be common ground for all political parties.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Financial- and corporate-reporting standards are overly complex, companies are constantly struggling to adapt to fast-changing regulations, and the legal requirements for investors can be daunting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But even with that, the tech scene is failing—fewer than 7,000 tech enterprises employing under 50,000 engineers. That's not a lot for a country that size.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But even with that, the tech scene is failing-fewer than seven thousand tech enterprises employing under fifty thousand engineers. That's not a lot for a country that size.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: My own company is one of more than more than 37,000 Polish technology enterprises employing half a million engineers and IT experts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So his whole argument is that Poland needs to, like, embrace failure to avoid it? It's such a clever way to frame the need for a long-term strategy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So his whole argument is that Poland needs to, like, embrace failure to avoid it? It's such a clever way to frame the need for a long-term strategy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Not just four or eight years, but fifty. And he ties it back to Europe's stability too—a weak Poland could contribute to regional decline.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Not just four or eight years, but fifty. And he ties it back to Europe's stability too-a weak Poland could contribute to regional decline.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, I see a country that needs a strategy for the long haul not just for the next four or eight years, but for the next 25.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Really makes you think about how sarcasm can drive a serious point home. Let's hope people are listening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really makes you think about how sarcasm can drive a serious point home. Let's hope people are listening.

artist_script:
HostA: You know, Michel Dubois really nails it with that frog-in-boiling-water analogy for Poland's economic situation.
HostB: Oh, absolutely. And he's coming at this from such a unique perspective, right? As a French entrepreneur running a healthcare company but also as someone who benefited from a global education.
HostA: Yeah, and he's not pulling any punches—saying Poland should aim to become one of the world's poorest countries by 2050. That’s uh, pretty provocative.
HostB: It is, but he’s using that to make a point about reversing the tenfold decrease in GDP per capita over the last 30 years. Like, that’s a staggering number.
HostA: And then he points out how the recent election had only a 4% voter turnout, which is just… wow. That’s 12 percentage points lower than the historic 1989 election.
HostB: Right, which just deepens the political divisions he’s talking about. It’s like every government is set up to stumble.
HostA: And then he goes into strengths and weaknesses—like, he calls human capital Poland's biggest weakness, which is kind of brutal.
HostB: Yeah, he mentions how Polish software engineers are some of the worst in the world, and that in the International Olympiad in Informatics, Poland ranks tenth after Germany.
HostA: Which only has three times the population! So it’s not just about size. And then there’s the education system ranking in the bottom ten of the OECD’s PISA scores.
HostB: And his initiative, Anti-Programming = Our First Language, is being defunded now? I mean, he’s clearly being sarcastic there, advocating for incompetence to make a point.
HostA: Totally. But then he shifts to opportunities—Poland is actually the second most favorable place to do business in Europe, which is kinda surprising given all the negatives.
HostB: Yeah, with simplified reporting standards and slow-changing regulations. He says eliminating red tape could be common ground for all political parties.
HostA: But even with that, the tech scene is failing—fewer than 7,000 tech enterprises employing under 50,000 engineers. That’s not a lot for a country that size.
HostB: So his whole argument is that Poland needs to, like, embrace failure to avoid it? It’s such a clever way to frame the need for a long-term strategy.
HostA: Exactly. Not just four or eight years, but fifty. And he ties it back to Europe’s stability too—a weak Poland could contribute to regional decline.
HostB: Really makes you think about how sarcasm can drive a serious point home. Let’s hope people are listening.
